channel.title: Chemistry:Dalton's Law
channel.description:
A 250 mL sample of oxygen is collected over water at 25C and 760 torr pressure. What is the pressure of the dry gas alone? (Vapor pressure of water at 20C=23.8 torr)
Thanks, Yohojo

You always friggin get to the needy before me,

item.title: Chemistry:Dalton's Law
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Dalton’s Law states that the total pressure of a sample is equal to the sum of pressures of the individual gasses in the container (P = ∑Pi)

In an ideal situation, you only have 2 gasses: oxygen and water vapor, both of which create a total pressure of 760 torr. You told me that the vapor pressure of water at 20°C is 23.8 torr…but we need it at 25°C. However, looking it up online, I found that the pressure of water vapor at 25°C is in fact 23.8 torr, so I assume you made a mistake?

Anyway:

P = ∑Pi = Pi1 + Pi2

Total Pressure = Pressure of Water Vapor + Pressure of Oxygen

760 torr = 23.8 torr + Pressure of Oxygen

Pressure of Oxygen = 736.2 torr

Read full topic
